data.title: “NATO has stolen, Ukraine has smoked ...”
data.meta_description: After the Chicago summit, Ukraine’s last hopes for joining NATO melted. Having received a turn from the gate, the country proclaimed the “non-alignment” of the state. Obviously, pondering time
data.text:
After the Chicago summit, Ukraine’s last hopes for joining NATO melted. Having received a turn from the gate, the country proclaimed the “non-alignment” of the state. Obviously, Kiev had little time to think about its maneuver. Otherwise, the country would not be in the "boiler", surrounded on all sides by enemies.

Threats of non-aligned status

Neutral status, with all its attractiveness, loses in peacetime a number of advantages that it gives to the military. In fact, de jure neutral Ukraine is now forced to "dig trenches" in all directions. Previously, only Russia was among the likely enemies of the country, but now Turkey is in the South, Poland is in the Northwest, and Romania is in the West. Hence a different approach to the facts that Kiev had previously turned a blind eye to. Ukrainian military experts, seeing clearly, sounded the alarm. The military budget of neighboring Poland over the past decade an average of six times higher than the Ukrainian. Ample purchases of unmanned aerial vehicles are in full swing. The Air Force adopted the American multi-role fighter with modern high-precision weapons F-16 Blok52. Also available Tanks Leopard-2, Spike-lr ATGM, S-130 and S-295 transport aircraft, Perry frigates.

The Black Sea was “saddled” by another failed NATO ally, Turkey, where the construction of eight new frigates worth 7 billion dollars is in full swing. In addition, the development of a ground-to-ground missile with a radius of 200 km has been completed. The Turkish Army Modernization Plan before 2016 provides for the development and supply of tanks, combat aircraft, attack and transport helicopters, as well as the main classes of local-made warships. At the end of 2012, Ankara achieved the deployment of Patriot air defense systems on its territory - in January, 2013 delivered two batteries of these sets to Turkey.

Not even the most formidable Romania has become a likely opponent of Ukraine. In the fall of 2012, the command of its armed forces announced their intention to acquire the 12 old F-16 Fighting Falcon fighter in Portugal. In terms of non-aligned status, Kiev is forced to regard the Romanian plans as a threat to its national security.

Ukraine has just begun to realistically assess its geo-strategic position. Ukrainian military experts have yet to assess the plans for deploying elements of the American missile defense system in Europe in Poland, Romania and Turkey. And here Kiev awaits a truly unpleasant surprise, since all the components of the European missile defense system are located right around the perimeter of Ukraine. For example, ships equipped with the Aegis system and SM-3 missiles ply in the Mediterranean, the mobile AN / TPY-2 THAAD mobile radar system is on alert in the Turkish city of Malatya. Before 2015, the SM-3 sea and land-based missiles will appear near Kiev in Romania. By 2018, the installation of the same missiles in Poland is planned, as well as the replacement of old versions with a new SM-3 Block IIA. And for a snack - the re-equipment of all units for a new modification of the SM-3 Block IIB missiles. The United States also intends to launch the Precision Tracking Space System (PTSS) and the Airborne Infrared Detection System - Airborne Infrared (ABIR), which, according to Americans, will be able to track up to several hundred rockets simultaneously.

Rustles cause analytical "nix" in Kiev

Fear has large eyes, and “non-alignment” is a state where it seems that there is an enemy behind every bush. Perhaps, being in the heat of passion, Ukrainian military experts also added Belarus to the list of military threats. According to the Kiev Center for Army Studies, Minsk, although not as wasteful as Poland or Turkey, but also acts in building military muscles much more actively than Ukraine. At the same time, Belarus is charged with buying 8 ZRS C-300PMU1 in Russia, acquiring four C-300PS divisions, two Tor-М2 air defense systems, and finally signing a contract for the supply of the third battery of these complexes to Belarus. As you can see, we are talking exclusively about defensive armament. It is ridiculous, but even the fact that Minsk decided to purchase X-NUMX combat-training aircraft Yak-4 in the Russian Federation was received by the Ukrainian military experts with alarm.

“The defense policy of President Lukashenko only at first glance seems simple and uncomplicated. In fact, he closely follows fashion trends. IN drones, developed by local gunsmiths, which are planned for mass production in 2013, bypassing EU sanctions, engines manufactured by the German company 3W Modellmotoren were used. As a result, starting this year, Minsk plans to annually produce 10 Sterkh-BM UAVs for its law enforcement agencies, the CIA experts conclude. At the same time, they completely lose sight of other facts that are really important for assessing real, and not mythical challenges and threats - this is the absence of any significant Belarusian groupings of troops on the northern borders of Ukraine. A gesture that directly indicates the trust and desire of Belarus to further develop friendly relations with its southern neighbor.

Non-blocking status - more expensive

Neutral status, for all its appeal, is the most expensive option for ensuring national security. This status, which requires readiness to repel potential aggression from any side, presupposes a large army and, consequently, funding for its maintenance and technical equipment.

Having declared “non-aligned”, Ukraine focused on Switzerland, Austria and Finland. The military budgets of the Swiss and Finnish armies amount to 3 billion dollars and 2,78 billion euros. In Ukraine, for the needs of the military department, in the 2013 year, costs are planned in the amount of 15,7 billion hryvnia or 1,96 billion dollars. That is, the financial capabilities of the Ukrainian armed forces for upgrading weapons and providing material allowances for personnel in 1,4-2,1 are less than the times of the two European countries mentioned.

But after all, Switzerland and Finland are significantly inferior to Ukraine in terms of area, number of population, and number of units of large energy and industrial facilities that require constant military cover. In addition, they lack such potential threats as the territorial claims of the revanchist forces of Romania against the Ukrainian Bukovina, Hungary against the Transcarpathia, and Russia towards the Crimea.

The only option with this approach may be to recruit an army on the basis of universal conscription. A classic example is the modern Belarusian armed forces. Why the northern neighbor of Ukraine does not refuse to call? Firstly, the construction of the Belarusian army on the basis of universal military duty and the presence of a developed system of training of reservists at scheduled gatherings allows to achieve the required efficiency. Secondly, this makes it possible, in the event of a real military threat, to increase the number of armies to 200 thousand during the first hours of mobilization deployment and about another 1 million in a short time. Thirdly, it serves as a means of conducting a gender policy - men in Belarus become and remain men.

In addition, the territorial defense system is successfully developing in Belarus. The control system of the “militia” in places is built according to the territorial principle, there is a territorial-zonal structure - the territory of Belarus is divided into zones of territorial defense, whose borders coincide with the administrative-territorial borders of the regions and Minsk. Zones consist of areas of territorial defense, areas - of the relevant objects. A separate rifle battalion and a separate rifle company are formed in each district in case of war.

The main body of the territorial defense command is the general headquarters, which directs the territorial troops through the territorial defense directorate. But the main responsibility for the state of territorial defense in the districts and regions is assigned to the chairmen of regional executive committees and district executive committees. This is a feature of the Belarusian “militia” system, the experience of which can be used by Ukraine as well.

By the way, in the army of neutral Switzerland, Austria and Finland, they also retained universal military service. On this issue, a referendum was held to transfer the army on a professional basis. The population of these countries spoke in favor of maintaining universal conscription. The last such referendum was held in Austria 20 January 2013 of the year.

"Fatal eggs" of Ukraine

A modern Ukrainian politician with “independent” thinking is reminiscent of that Bulgakov collective farm chairman, who undertook to hatch the eggs of reptiles for himself. One such egg for Ukraine today is the idea of ​​a professional army. The announcement of the new Minister of Defense, Pavel Lebedev, about the transition of the Ukrainian armed forces to a contract basis already in 2013 was a surprise not only to the general public, but also to the local generals.

According to the defense minister, over the next few years, the Ukrainian army is planning to reduce from 182 thousand to 100 thousand. In fact, twice. In comparison with other armies, an interesting picture is obtained. Switzerland with an area of ​​41 284 square. km and the population of 7,7 million people retains universal military duty and has an army of a constant number of 22 thousand soldiers. Austria with an area of ​​83 871 square. km and population 8,4 million people - 41 thous. military. Finland, having an area of ​​338 430 square. km and population of 5,42 million, contains 16 800 military personnel.

If we take the average ratio of the number of armies to the area of ​​the country and the population, in Switzerland it is 1,69, Austria - 1,89, Finland - 1,58, Ukraine after reduction - 0,85. If we draw a link between the potential threats of an excessive reduction in the number of personnel of the Ukrainian army and the qualitative side of the possible consequences of the “reform” of the armed forces proclaimed by Lebedev, we can come to disappointing conclusions.

Another “fatal egg” of reformist thought is the idea of ​​uniting the Ministry of Defense and the Ministry of Emergency Situations. This December 29 announced President Viktor Yanukovych. In turn, Nikolai Chechetkin, deputy head of the Emergency Rescue Forces Management Department of the Emergencies Ministry, explained that “the ministry will be reorganized into the service and will perform the same tasks.”

Now in the Ukrainian army 55 thousand contract soldiers, 43 thousand soldiers and sergeants of military service. 15 thousand emchees and firefighters will join it. Reformers do not make any strategic calculations. Everything is explained by the logic of life, that the personnel of the armed forces of any country have always been and will be engaged to eliminate the consequences of the destructive natural (floods, earthquakes) and man-made disasters. That the army has a large number of engineering and other equipment that can be used for these purposes. On the other hand, the formal association of the military, emchees and firefighters within the same ministry carries great threats to the country's defense capability. The diversity of the control systems of each of these departments will sharply reduce the ability of the general staff to strategically deploy the armed forces with the onset of aggression.

The dangers of Ukrainian reform

Further weakening of the armed forces of Ukraine has one aspect: in the end, Kiev will lose in the face of the army a real foreign policy tool to maintain parity of conventional armed forces in the region. Indeed, for the time being, rivalry between states takes place in a latent form, but will it remain in such a state further? How long will Turkey, "saddling" the Bosphorus and the Dardanelles, will respect the international status of the strait? Will Romania want revenge on the still-Ukrainian Bukovina? And is Hungary forever abandoned the thought of Transcarpathia? In such circumstances, the idea of ​​"non-alignment" is not the most successful. Perhaps, it makes sense for Kiev to join the process of creating regional collective security systems with the participation of Belarus, Russia and Kazakhstan, and more actively develop military and military-technical cooperation with the CSTO countries. In addition to other other arguments in favor of this, there are clear economic advantages of joining the CU and CES.

Dmitry Kuibyshev

http://www.belvpo.com
